description: {"blocks":[{"key":"5r3ka","text":"Histone post-translational modifications are key epigenetic features that define gene regulatory elements in the  genome. Identifying changes in the epigenome has the potential to uncover novel disease signatures.  Chromatin immunoprecipitation with sequencing (ChIP-seq) is a commonly used method to define the  chromatin landscape. A limitation of this method is that the amount of starting material (â‰¥106 cells) does not  lend itself to interrogation of kidney biopsies. Cleavage Under Targets and Release Using Nuclease  (CUT\u0026RUN) is a recently described method that provides genome-wide mapping of chromatin profiles for histone binding. In this method, cells  are immobilized on beads, permeabilized with detergent (digitonin) and incubated with an antibody that recognizes specific histone post-translational modification in nucleosomes, DNA binding proteins (e.g., transcription factor) or other factors that associate with chromatin. After antibody binding, a fusion protein of Micrococcal nuclease and protein A/G (pAG-MNase) is added. The protein A/G moiety binds the antibody and  the nuclease cuts accessible chromatin adjacent to the nucleosomes. The released DNA fragments,  representing the genomic regions enriched for antibody binding, are column purified and used to construct a  library for sequencing. Sequence is aligned to the human genome and peaks that represent statistically  significant binding (e.g., histone H3 lysine 27 trimethylation, H3K27me3) are called using the Model-based  Analysis for ChIP-seq Method (Macs2) that we have adapted for CUT\u0026 RUN. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":406,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"8u83g","text":"The full CUT\u0026RUN protocol is from Epicypher (https://www.epicypher.com/content/documents/protocols/cutana-cut\u0026run-protocol.pdf). Please reference this protocol for full details and required positive and negative controls for experiments. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":45,"length":81}],"data":{}},{"key":"95hej","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bm4jm","text":"We outline a brief protocol with modifications for liquid nitrogen frozen human kidney tissue using 1.5 mL tubes and as little as 50,000 cells/CUT\u0026RUN antibody reaction. Depending on the abundance of the protein target and specificity of the antibody, it is possible to use less than 50,000 cells; however, we recommend using 50,000-500,000 cells/reaction.  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dg4k4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"4DD6E8B60DFE11EDB9BF0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.epicypher.com/content/documents/protocols/cutana-cut\u0026run-protocol.pdf"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2hn9a","text":"Trim fastq files to remove adapters using Cutadapt.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6ve72","text":"\nCommand Line Example: cutadapt -j 10 -m 10 -a AGATCGGAAGAG -A AGATCGGAAGAG -o R1.trim.fastq.gz -p R2.trim.fastq.gz R1.fastq.gz R2.fastq.gz","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"13u6j","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9m9id","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"92s8p","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8tukd","text":"By default, empty reads are kept. Set-minimum-length 10 to remove short/empty reads after trimming. Illumina Universal Adapters can be removed by using sequence: AGATCGGAAGAG. Run fastQC on fastq files to confirm adapter presence in raw fastq files and removal after trimming.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1gpnc","text":"Align trimmed fastq files to genome using Bowtie2 end to end mode.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8aqhc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"94pm7","text":"Command Line Example: bowtie2 --end-to-end --very-sensitive --no-mixed --no-discordant --phred33 -I 10 -X 700 -p 10 -x genome -1 R1.trim.fastq.gz -2 R2.trim.fastq.gz -S sample.sam","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"apm7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9e2q0","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"fm4ps","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"edv6d","text":"Set minimum and maximum fragment length as 10 and 700, respectively. ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6lvtc","text":"Use SAMtools view and sort commands to extract aligned reads from the resulting sam file and convert to a sorted bam file. Index the sorted bam file using SAMtools index.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3b7q7","text":"
 Command Line Example:
 a.	samtools view -bS -F 0x04 sample.sam > aligned.bam
 b.	samtools sort aligned.bam -o aligned.sort.bam
 c.	samtools index aligned.sort.bam","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d2nb7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"784v5","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"528a4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"9c016","text":"The SAMtools view and sort commands can be piped to reduce writing output of unnecessary temporary files. ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"91cvf","text":"Calculate sample normalization factor based on % of aligned E. coli  reads (as described in Epicypher Cut\u0026Run protocol).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d9qm7","text":"\n a. Calculate percent of aligned E. coli reads in all uniquely aligned reads (ex: 100,000 E. coli reads in 5,000,000   uniquely aligned reads = 2%).\n b. Calculate normalization factor to make E. coli spike in signal equal across all samples (ex: 1/2% = 0.5).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1tht1","text":"Generate scaled, binned bigWig file using Deeptools bamCoverage command with --scaleFactor parameter.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ber90","text":"\nCommand Line Example: bamCoverage -b aligned.sort.bam --scaleFactor 0.5 --binSize 50 --outFileFormat bigwig -o sample.bw","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"82otv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"r7ag","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"88td4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"9fjbj","text":"Blacklisted regions can be removed from the output bigwig file by including the - blackListFileName argument and providing a bed file of regions to exclude.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2skan","text":"Call peaks using Macs2. Use broad peak calling option for histone modifications.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"63gul","text":"\nCommand Line Example: macs2 callpeak -t aligned.sort.bam -c IgG.sort.bam -f BAM -g mm -n sample.name --broad --max-gap 1000 --min-length 160 --keep-dup all --fe-cutoff 2.7","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1q2sc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5amu0","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1m0hl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7tfc2","text":"--fe-cutoff parameter may be modified depending on sample quality and desired stringency level in peak calling.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}
